Course 4 Artist Vars 13_authored_hint.Course_4_Artist_Vars_13_a: You need two repeat loops (one inside the other) both repeating sides times.
Course 4 Artist Vars 13_authored_hint.Course_4_Artist_Vars_13_b:
The inner repeat loop draws an octagon (turning to the left).

Afterwards, you need to move forward and turn right only in the outer loop.
Course 4 Artist Vars 13_authored_hint.Course_4_Artist_Vars_13_c: To adjust the shape to stay the same size when the number of sides change, use the math block to divide the length in pixels by the number of sides.

Course 4 Artist Vars 6_authored_hint.Course_4_Artist_Vars_6_a: To draw a regular polygon, turn 360/sides each time.

Course 4 Artist Vars 8_authored_hint.Course_4_Artist_Vars_8_a: If you divide your starting length by the number of sides, the length of each side will get shorter as the number of sides gets higher.

Course 4 Bee Params 7_authored_hint.notice_pattern: Do you see a pattern in how the number of nectar changes?
Course 4 Bee Params 7_authored_hint.count_with_for: Notice that the nectar goes up in steps. What kind of block can you use to do the same thing many times while counting up?

Course 4 Bee Params 8_authored_hint.Course_4_Bee_Params_8_a: It's okay to ask for a honey number and a nectar number each time. If there's none of something, the number can be 0.

Course 4 Play Lab Params 2_authored_hint.Course_4_Play_Lab_Params_2_a: You will need to click "edit" on the jump function and update it so that it uses the height parameter.

Course 4 Play Lab Vars 2_authored_hint.Course_4_Play_Lab_Vars_2_a: Make sure to set the number for dog_speed to something larger than cat_speed.

Course 4 Play Labs For Loops 2_authored_.Course_4_Play_Labs_For_Loops_2_a: What would you add to your for loop every time to skip the even numbers?

Course 4 Playlab For Loops 4b_authored_h.Course_4_Playlab_For_Loops_4b_a: The flags are about 330 pixels away from the characters.
Course 4 Playlab For Loops 4b_authored_h.Course_4_Playlab_For_Loops_4b_b: How can you make each character reach 330 pixels in the same number of moves with different starting and stopping numbers?
Course 4 Playlab For Loops 4b_authored_h.Course_4_Playlab_For_Loops_4b_c: Remember, it doesn't matter how much a character passes the flag by on its last step, as long as it takes each character the same number of steps to get to the flag.

Course 4 Playlab For Loops 5b_authored_h.Course_4_Playlab_For_Loops_5b_a: The characters are about 175 pixels away from the center.
Course 4 Playlab For Loops 5b_authored_h.Course_4_Playlab_For_Loops_5b_b: Remember, a character's next step will be longer than their last, since the counter keeps getting larger.

Before you draw the third row of hexagons, you need to turn right by 60 degrees and jump forward 40 pixels.

Once you're in the correct vertical location, you have to turn your artist back again and jump backward 440 pixels (120 pixels farther than your shift down/forward function.

2 draw a hexagon 6 moveForward 40 turnRight 60 shift down/backward turnRight 60 jumpForward 40 turnLeft 60 jumpBackward 440 draw a line of hexagons 3 jumpForward 120 shift down/forward turnRight 60 jumpForward 40 turnLeft 60 jumpBackward 320

Before you draw the second row of octagons, you need to turn right by 45 degrees and jump forward 96 pixels.

Once you're in the correct vertical location, you have to turn your artist back again and jump backward 408 pixels.
Course 4 SCF 2_authored_hint.Course_4_SCF_2_d:
Notice that because there are fewer octagons in the even rows, you don't have to jump back any further to get to the starting place for the odd rows.

This means you can use the same function for all rows.

2 2 3 2 draw octagons numOctagons jumpForward 136 draw an octagon 8 moveForward 40 turnRight 45 shift down turnRight 45 jumpForward 96 turnLeft 45 jumpBackward 408

Course 4 SCF 3_authored_hint.Course_4_SCF_3_b: This is a series of octagons with sides that are counter pixels long.
Course 4 SCF 3_authored_hint.Course_4_SCF_3_c: Each octagon is called from inside a for loop that goes from 200 down to 2 by 2.
Course 4 SCF 3_authored_hint.Course_4_SCF_3_d: Don't forget to turn by 22.5 degrees at the end of each iteration.
Course 4 SCF 3_authored_hint.Course_4_SCF_3_e: Both the color of each octagon and the width of the pen are controlled by the counter variable.
Course 4 SCF 3_authored_hint.Course_4_SCF_3_f:
Solution:

draw an octagon 8 moveForward length turnRight 45 200 2 2 MINUS 255 counter counter MULTIPLY counter 2 DIVIDE counter 4 counter turnLeft 22.5

The other for loop only needs one regular loop to make counter amount of honey.

Course 4 SCFL 4_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_4_a: The color change happens using the set color with red, green, blue block. Red is always the value of counter, green is always 255 - counter, and blue remains constant at 255 exactly.
Course 4 SCFL 4_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_4_b: Each shape is a square with sides that are counter pixels long, starting with 5px, and increasing by 5px all the way up to 200px.
Course 4 SCFL 4_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_4_c: The artist turns 15 degrees between each square.
Course 4 SCFL 4_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_4_d:
Solution:

1 5 200 5 counter MINUS 255 counter 255 4 moveForward counter turnRight 90 turnLeft 15

Course 4 SCFL 6_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_6_a: The color change happens using the set color with red, green, blue block. Red is set constant at 255, green is always the value of counter, and blue is always 255 - counter.
Course 4 SCFL 6_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_6_b: The code for this is much more simple than you might think. Just set the color inside the for loop, move forward, then turn.
Course 4 SCFL 6_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_6_d:
Solution:

1 5 250 2 255 counter MINUS 255 counter moveForward counter turnRight 80

Course 4 SCFL 7_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_7_a: The color change happens using the set color with red, green, blue block. Red is set to counter. Green is 255 - counter, and blue is set constant at 255.
Course 4 SCFL 7_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_7_b: This drawing is made using two similar for loops. One goes from 5 to 200 by 2, the other goes from 200 to 5 by 2.
Course 4 SCFL 7_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_7_c: Inside each for loop you move forward 5 pixels before you turn by 360 / counter. Don't forget to set your brush to width counter before you do!
Course 4 SCFL 7_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_7_d: You'll need to turn left by 225 degrees between the two for loops.
Course 4 SCFL 7_authored_hint.Course_4_SCFL_7_e:
Solution:

20 5 200 2 counter counter MINUS 255 counter 255 moveForward 5 turnLeft DIVIDE 360 counter turnLeft 225 200 5 2 counter counter MINUS 255 counter 255 moveForward 5 turnRight DIVIDE 360 counter

Course 4 SCV 1_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_1_a: Variables are helpful because you can add to them each time through a loop.
Course 4 SCV 1_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_1_b: This puzzle has one loop that creates the polygon, one loop that repeats the polygon sides times, then another loop that does it all again after adding 5 to sides.
Course 4 SCV 1_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_1_c: Using a variable for sides and one for length makes the code cleaner because you can loop the same code multiple times, instead of creating a new copy for each set of numbers.
Course 4 SCV 1_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_1_d:
Solution:

1 length 500 sides 0 2 sides ADD sides 5 sides sides moveForward DIVIDE length sides turnLeft DIVIDE 360 sides turnRight DIVIDE 360 sides

The completed image is made up of 10 of these "flowers":

...which are made up of 10 of these decagons:
Course 4 SCV 2_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_2_b: This design uses nested loops (three deep). All loops run sides times.
Course 4 SCV 2_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_2_c: The artist turns to the left when creating each decagon, but turns to the right in both of the other loops.
Course 4 SCV 2_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_2_d: To prevent all of your 10 petal "flowers" from getting drawn in the same place, make sure to jump forward by length/sides before you turn 360/sides degrees as part of your outermost loop.
Course 4 SCV 2_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_2_e:
Solution:

1 length 400 sides 10 sides #ff0000 sides sides moveForward DIVIDE length sides turnLeft DIVIDE 360 sides turnRight DIVIDE 360 sides jumpForward DIVIDE length sides turnRight DIVIDE 360 sides

Course 4 SCV 4_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_4_b: It will be very helpful to use three loops inside of your main loop. One for moving forward, one for collecting nectar and one for making honey.

honey 4 nectar 6 5 MINUS nectar 1 nectar honey turnRight honey ADD honey 1 nectar MINUS nectar 1

Course 4 SCV 5_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_5_a: Take a look at this option for movement:
Course 4 SCV 5_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_5_b: Each time through the loop, the flowers have two less nectar and the bee needs to make one more honey.
Course 4 SCV 5_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_5_c: Notice that at the beginning of the outside loop, the bee moves as many times as there is nectar in the next flower.

Solution:

honey 1 nectar 5 3 nectar moveForward turnRight nectar moveForward honey honey ADD honey 1 nectar MINUS nectar 2

Course 4 SCV 6_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_6_a: Take a look at what a single completed shape looks like
Course 4 SCV 6_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_6_b: You will benefit from creating 8 variables: red1, green1, blue1, red2, green2, blue2, length, and sides.
Course 4 SCV 6_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_6_c: Each of the shape's 5 sides is broken up into pieces of length/sides where the zig is teal (rgb = 0,175,200) and the zag is purple (rgb = 100, 50, 150).
Course 4 SCV 6_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_6_d: To zig, turn left by 360/sides. To zag, turn right by 360/sides.
Course 4 SCV 6_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_6_e: The rest of the program is very standard for making a full 360 degree rotation from a shape, except that we are overlapping the shapes by half, so we have to turn right by 180/sides, which means that we need twice as many of them as usual (sides*2 repetitions).
Course 4 SCV 6_authored_hint.Course_4_SCV_6_f:
Solution:

1 red1 0 green1 175 blue1 200 red2 100 green2 50 blue2 150 length 70 sides 5 MULTIPLY 2 sides sides sides red1 green1 blue1 moveForward DIVIDE length sides turnLeft DIVIDE 360 sides red2 green2 blue2 moveForward DIVIDE length sides turnRight DIVIDE 360 sides turnRight DIVIDE 360 sides turnRight DIVIDE 180 sides

NEW Course 4 Artist Params inspire_autho.double_loop: Try putting a for loop inside of a repeat loop.
NEW Course 4 Artist Params inspire_autho.specifics:
The for loop runs from three to seventeen for each of the six "petals" before moving on to create the next, drawing shapes with only an odd number of sides.

The set alpha block uses division to fade the color as the counter gets higher.
NEW Course 4 Artist Params inspire_autho.after: When you're done with each "petal", be sure to move forward 20 pixels before you make a 60 degree rotation.
NEW Course 4 Artist Params inspire_autho.solution:
Solution

1 #0000cd 6 3 17 2 DIVIDE 500 counter 30 counter moveForward 20 turnRight 60

aE3_authored_hint.aE3_b:
Don't forget to move the artist down before you start a new row of shapes!

To move the artist down and get him facing the right way again, make sure to:

  • Turn 90 degrees (to face down)
  • Jump 20 pixels (to get to new row)
  • Turn back 90 degrees (to face right again)
aE3_authored_hint.aE3_c: When you're all done, your nested loops should be three repeats deep.

nectarRemaining > 0

If you repeat the above actions twice, you will be ready to move back down the main path.

350 200

This jump to block lets you move the zombie artist to any pixel on the grid, whenever you want. It works by moving him a number of pixels over to the right and a number of pixels down. This is always counted from the top left corner, which it means it doesn't matter where the zombie artist is before the command is run!

courseE_playLab_challenge1_authored_hint.courseE_playLab_challenge1_a:
Here are some things you could do when the player wins the game:

  • Make the dinosaur vanish.
  • Stop the squirrels.
  • Make the squirrels and knight happy.
  • Set a new background.
  • Make the knight thank the player for helping.
  • Make all of the actors vanish and show a "You Win!" message.
courseE_playLab_challenge1_authored_hint.courseE_playLab_challenge1_b:
Here are some things you could do when the player loses the game:

  • Make the knight vanish.
  • Make the squirrels sad.
  • Make the dinosaur say something.
  • Set a new background.
  • Make all of the actors vanish and show a "Game Over" message.

level 'grade3_Loops_12_authored_hint.2-3_Bee_Loops_6_a: If you can't tell what should go into the repeat loop, try dragging blocks out one by one and see if you can find a pattern.
level 'grade3_Loops_12_authored_hint.2-3_Bee_Loops_6_b: There should be 6 blocks inside your repeat loop when you're done.

level 'grade3_Loops_4_authored_hint.2-3_Bee_Loops_3B_a: You will need two different repeat loops, one after the other.

level 'grade3_Loops_5_authored_hint.2-3_Bee_Loops_7_a: The first action will be a turn, rather than a move.
level 'grade3_Loops_5_authored_hint.2-3_Bee_Loops_7_b: If you can't quite picture the loop from the beginning, try coding it out the long way, then look for a pattern.

level 'grade3_Loops_6_authored_hint.2-3_Bee_Loops_4A_a: The first action will be a turn, rather than a move.

sample3_authored_hint.sample3_a: Try writing the code once and looping it seven times:

sample5_authored_hint.sample5_a: Did you know that you can put as many blocks inside of a repeat loop as you want to?
sample5_authored_hint.sample5_b:
The bee is looping these actions over and over again:

  • move forward
  • make honey
  • turn left
  • move forward
  • turn right

sample6_authored_hint.sample6_a: Did you know that you can use more than one repeat loop in a puzzle?
sample6_authored_hint.sample6_b: Sometimes repeat loops have lots of blocks inside, and sometimes they might only have one!
